9.text:
Have you ever noticed that when you’re working
in rib and you’re doing stripes that sometimes

13.text:
you’ll have kind of a muddy edge where one
color runs into the other?

17.text:
I’m going to show you a couple of techniques
for making really clean stripes in ribbing,

23.text: especially if you’re ribbing in the round.

28.text: Here is my bad example, down here.

31.text:
I’ve gone from pink to this cream color,
and I have what I call a muddy line, because

37.text:
the pink is partially, or the cream is partially
in the pink here.

41.text: And here is a better example.

43.text:
Here is a clean break, that no color is leaking
over into the other one.

51.text:
And to get that, what we do right after we
change colors, on that first round or that

62.text:
Plain knitting, we were working 2 by 2 rib,
and now it’s just plain knitting.

67.text:
And of course, that seems wrong, and it seems
like it would show in your work, and it does

73.text:
show if you stretch it out like this, you’ll
see that you have a round of knitting there.

79.text:
But when you’re not stretching it, when
it’s just flat, the row of knitting kind

83.text:
of tucks itself into the work like that and
you don’t see it at all.

86.text:
Now the next little trick you can do, is to
avoid a color change jog, when you’re going

94.text:
from one color to the next in knitting in
the round.

97.text: Again, here is my bad example.

99.text:
My first cream colored stitch is here, and
the last one is way up here.

105.text:
This is the break. This is the beginning of
the round right here. You end up with this

110.text:
And this is where I corrected it. You can
still tell that it is the beginning of the

114.text: round, but it is much smoother.

116.text:
And this technique also works for stockinette,
or just plain knitting.

120.text:
To get this, you take the right leg of the
stitch below, in the old color, and put it

127.text:
up on the needle with the first stitch in
the new color.

134.text:
You only do that on the first stitch, of the
second round, of the new color.

139.text: You only have to do it once.

140.text:
You’ll do this every time you change colors,
though.

142.text:
And then you just continue with the rib, as
before.

150.text:
These techniques work for whatever kind of
rib you’re doing – 1 by 1, 3 by 1, whatever.

154.text:
Because the muddy color break happens in ribbing,
kind of uniquely in ribbing, and the color

160.text:
change jog is good when you’re working in
the round.

162.text: And those are how to get clean stripes.
